page.title: 01STH WINGFIELD-AREA SUMMARY
page.content: South Wingfield probably takes its name from the "win" which is the ancient name for common gorse. It is a rural area with much of the farmland being under grass. The landscape is gently undulating with some deciduous tree cover. Dry stone walls or hedgerows mark field boundaries.The River Amber flows on a north/south route through the area. The most notable buildings are Wingfield Manor, partly destroyed in the Civil War, and the Parish Church which is of Norman origin. Approximately 1,900 people live in the area. Most people travel outside the area for employment and to shop. Public transport is provided by a once hourly bus service to Alfreton and Matlock.
